interface.name: org_kde_kwin_screen_management
interface.description:
This interface allows to connected output devices for screen configuration purposes.
- keep protocol flat for simplicity, use id to tell which output this signal refers to - provide info about all outputs, per OutputDevice:
events: - outputdevice_added - id (unique int, only handed out by kwin, used to identify and refer to an OD throughout the protocol) - resolution: resX, resY - position: posX, posY - orientation: degree - primary: bool - enabled: bool - modes: width, height, refresh_rate (separate signal) - edid: eisa_id, monitor_name, serial_number, physical_width, physical_height (separate signal) - outputdevice_removed: id
methods: - per outputdevice: - set enabled - set mode - set orientation - set position - set primary - apply: client is done sending set* calls, "dear compositor, please apply the settings now"
server: - wayland_server.cpp gets a ScreenManagement interface - initOutputs also triggers events in the screenmanagement interface - announces the outputs on the ScreenManagementInterface when bound - sends device announced, edid and mode callbacks in order - solely responsible for handing out ids - is responsible for state changes through backends - decides what to do with the information
client: - connects to server - receives the info about all the outputs - ignores wl_output otherwise - can set properties of outputs (enable/disable, mode, position, etc.)
why? - keeps everything in one place - one interface for a specific purpose - bi-directional, so defined config interface, no config writing/picking up etc. - one place to housekeep ids - interface is purpose-made, not trying to shoe-horn kscreen in and around wl_output - server really seems to be the right place to keep state and logic - makes concertation less complex, since there's exactly one place to handle state, like mode, on/off, etc.

event.name: disabled_output_added

description.summary: emitted when anutp output is connected

event.description: The output is connected, but not used for rendering yet. This means that this output has either just been plugged in, or disabled and excluded from the registry object.

event.name: disabled_output_removed

description.summary: emitted when an output disappears from the list

event.description: The output is disconnected, or has been enabled.

event.name: outputdevice_added

description.summary: emitted when an output is connected

event.description: The output is connected, but not used for rendering yet. This means that this output has either just been plugged in, or disabled and excluded from the registry object.

arg.name: enabled
arg.summary: is the output currently used to display screen content?

arg.name: primary
arg.summary: is the output the primary display?

event.name: edid

description.summary: emitted when an output disappears from the list

event.description: EDID information for an output is announced.

arg.name: id
arg.summary: the ID of the output for this EDID information

arg.name: eisa_id
arg.summary: EISA ID of the output device

arg.name: monitor_name
arg.summary: human-readable name of the output device

arg.name: serial_number
arg.summary: serial number of the output device

event.name: mode

description.summary: emitted per mode and per outputdevice

event.description: A new mode is announced for a given output.

arg.name: id
arg.summary: the ID of the output this mode applies to

arg.name: refresh_rate
arg.summary: human-readable name of the output device

event.name: outputdevice_removed

description.summary: emitted when an output disappears from the list

event.description: The output is disconnected or otherwise gone.

event.name: done

description.summary: emitted after all initial events have been fired

event.description: This event is fired once the listing of outputdevices triggered after binding the protocol is done, i.e. after all outputs, their edid and their modes have been announced. In case there are no outputdevices, this event is fired anyway.
